the horizon, night was fast approaching, and
the poor Wanderer knew not where to rest
his weary limbs. Fatigued and almost
exhausted, he came at last near village
He was glad to find it inhabited, thinking
where human beings dwelt, there dwelt al
so humanity and compassion, but he was
mistaken. He asked for nights lodging,
it was refused. Not one of the inhospitable

to find hospitable roof to protect me against
the inclemency Of the weather; bur God is

claimed he, must not be permitted even
to pursue my favourite study' Bur God is

HE stretched himself on the bare earth.
willing, if possible to have a few hours
sleep. He had scarcely closed his eyes,
when fierce wolf came and killed the cock
What new misfortune is this!' calculated
the astonished Akiba.-'My vigilant compan-


ion is gone Who then, will henceforth a.
waken me to the study of the law9 But,
God is just; he knows best zuhat is good for
lts hoor mortais.-Scarcely had he fin


shed the sentence, when terrible lion

my lamp and my cock are gone; my poor
ass too is gone--all is gone But hraised
be the Lord, qvhate1er he does is for the best


He passed sleepess night, and early in


the morning went to the village, to see


whether he could procure horse, or any


beast Of burden, to enable him to pursue his
journey. But what was his surprise, not to
| find single individual alive


sit appears that band ofrobbers had en-
tered the village during the night, killed its
inhabitants, and plundered their houses. AS
soon as Akiba had sufficiently recovered
from the amazement into which this won-
derful occurrence had thrown him, he lifted
up his voice and exclaimed, Thou Great
God, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
now know by experience, that poor mortal


men are short sighted and blind, often con-
sdcri2s as evils, what is intended tor their
preservation! But thou alone art kind and
mercifu! Had not the hard-hearted peo-
Pile driven ME by their inhospitality from the
village. should assuredly have shared their
fate. Had not the wind extinguished my
lamp the robbers would have been drawn to
the spot, and have murdered me. l per-
ceve also that it was thy mercy which de-
prived me of my two companions, that they
! might not by their noise, give notice to the
banditti where was. Praised, then, be thy
name for ever and ever!"

pally employed with general Gates, in sur

For the materials of this hasty sketch,
our obligations are due to major Caleb Stark
his eldest son, who participated with his IL
lustrious father in many OF the perls OF the
revolution.


At the conclusion of the war, General
Stark, like the Roman Cincinnatus, retired
to the pursuits of domestic life, mingling
with the illustrious and hardy yeomanry Of
New England, and aspiring to none OF the
honors CT emolunents Of public Office; but
reaping, IN common with his countrymen,
the fruits Of that immortal struggle which
made us free people. For the last few
years OF his life, he enjoyed pecuniary
bounty from Governmental free will offer
ing Of the nation to ONT. Of its most ditinguish
ed defenders.


Such was General Stark ,---the last surviv-
ing general officer of the rcyulution--the
first and most intrepid hero Of cur state, Of


whom she may justly boast, as unsurpassed
in cool and determined bravery. lie has
gone the way Of all the living. His charac-
ter in private life was unembellished. Hi,


manners were frank and artless, though
tnged with an eccentrlcity peculiar to hi.
family alone. 10 sam up all, he was tina,
"nobest work of God" an honest man.

This famous wall which formerly sepa-


rated England from Scotland, many parts of


which still exist, and which even time has


not injured. The strength of the cement
and the hardness of the stone have persuad-
ed the inhabitants of the adjoining district
that it was built by the hand of the devil;
and the more superstitous amongst them
are very anxious to collect the smallest re-


mains of it. which they mix with the foun-
dation OF their houses, in order to give them
greater solility. A Scotch gardener, on


digging in the soil of his garden, found


stone of considerable size, upon which


was an inscription in the dialect of the peri


cd, purportlng that it had been placed there


for the security OF the walls ofthe castle and


of the garden, and that it had been brought
thther from the great wall, of which it had
formerly constituted part; but that there


would be as much danger in moving it. as
there would be advantage in leaving it in its
place. The owner of the estate, who was
less credulols than this ancestors. wished to
have it transported to another spot, in order
to expose it to public view as an ancient
monument. Workmen were employed to
raise it from the ground by means of ma
chinery, and they succeeded, as they would
have done with a common stone. 1t remain
Gu ui''u tHS St5C VI lHC WuDC tulioa-
ity induced several persons to descend into
the cavity, amongst the rest the gardener,
several servants and the two sons OF the
proprietor, who amused themselves for some
time il digging in the hole. The fatal stone
which had not been placed in a just equili-
brium, chose that moment for falling to the
bottom Of the cavity, and crushed all those
who were in it. The young wife of the ell
der ofthe two brothers soon learnt what had
She hurried to the garden, with
the wild transports of u woman who has no
thing left in the world TO care for; and she
arrived at the time when the workmen were
using their utmost efforts to raise the stone
again, ii the faint hope of finding some re-
mains Of life in the unfortunate sufferers
whom it covered. They had half raised it,
and it was in fact perceived, by certain


that they still breathed, when
the imprudent wife, losing all care tor her
self threw herself so precipitately on the
body Of her husband, that the workmen,
petrined BY her action, unfortunately let go
the machines which supported the stone,
and buried her VITA the others. This acci-
dent still further confirmed the superstition
Of the Scotch; they failed not to attribute it
to some power established for the preserva.
tion of the wall of Scotland, and all OF the
stones which have been detached from il.

From Dicks Christian Philosopher.


The discoveries which have been made in the


System of Nature illustrate the doctrine of the


Resurrection ofthe dead.


The Doctrine of Resurrection of the
DEAD, at hrSt view, appears to involve III IT
a variety of difficulties and apparent con-
tradictions. That a complex organical ma
chine, as the human body is, consisting of
thousands of diversified parts, for the per-
formance of its functions, after being reduced
70 atoms, and those atoms scattered to "the
four winds of Heavcn"-should be again
reared up with the same materials, in a new
and more glorious form, is an idea which
seems to battle the human comprehen
sion; and. in all probability, would never
nave entered the mind of man, had it not
neen communicated by Divine Revelation
Accordingly, we find that the philosophers
OF antiquity, though many Of them believed
IN future state, never once dreamed that
The bodies of men, after they had been COM
mitted to the dust, would ever again be re-
animated; and hence, when the Apostle
raul proposed this doctrine to the Athenian
philosophers, they secuted the idea, as if it
mad been the reverie of madman. And,
nideed, without strong conviction, and a
hvely impression of the infinite power and
intelligence of God, the mind cannot rely
with mistaken confidence on the declaration
Sl =, future fact so widely different from all
.,le OBVIOUS phenomena of nature, and from
every thing that lies within the range of hu.
man experience. "If man tlie," says Job,
snail he live again? There is hope of a
.ree, 1t be cut down, that it will sprout a.
haalh' a' and bring forth boughs like plant
Out nas man dicth and wasteth away, yea, man
5MWeth up the ghost, and where is hee"
maen the mind. however, is frequently ex-
asas s,ssed IN contemplations on the stupendous
nraa nurks OF the Almighty, it must feel an i'm
Sssslve Sars conviction, "that nothing can be too
ths1 husa ior Jehovah" When we endeavor to
shs INV aside the veil which conceals many of
|IIls s.enes OF nature from the vulgar eye,

In the number of the London Quarterly
Review Just received, some amusing extracts
are made from "Eurwitz's Hcbre.v fatc@,
selected from the writings of the ancient

"Compelled by violent persecution to
quit his native land, Rabbi Akiba wandered
over barren wastes and dreary deserts. His
whole equipage consisted Ola lamp, which
he used to light at night, in order to study
the law; cock, which served him instead
of watch, to announce to him the rising
dawn: and an ass, on which he rode.

On scanty and bold projection of rock,


stands the ruins Of the Kienast, SO separat-


ed on all sides from the body of the noun


tain, by PERCEPTIONS hills, except where a


narrow hedge en the south connects it with


the hill, that the rising of a single draw


bride must have rendered it inaccessible


Enough Of TIE outer wall still remains, to


preserve tic memory of the fair Cunigunda,


equally celebrated for her charms and her


cruelty. She was the daughter and heiress


of the lord Of kienast, and the most bloom


inr of Silesian BEAUTIES. Her wealth and


charms attracted crowds of the knigty WOO


ers to her fathers castle; but the maiden,


like another Camilla, was entirely devoted


to the boisterous exercise of the chase, in


which. she excelled manv of her suffers; she


would listen to no tale of love, and dreaded


marriage as she did pr son. At length to


free herself from all opportunities She made


a solemn vow, never to give her hand but to
the knight who should ride round the castle
on the outer wall. Now, this wall is not
only too narrow to furnish secure or pleas
ing promenade in any circumstances, but
throughout nearly its whole course, it runs a
long the very brink of hideous precipices,
and in one place hangs over frghttul a
bvse, which, till this day, bears the name OF
Hell The number of the lady 8 lovers rap


dly diminished. The more prudent wise
ly considered that the prize was not worth
the risk; the vain proposed themselves to
the trial IN the hope that their presence
would molly Cungunda's heart, and procure
a lispensution from the hard condition; but
the mountain beauty was proof against all
arts, and when the moment OF danger came,
the courage of the suitor generally gave
way. History has not recorded the precise
number of those who actually made the at
tempt, it IS only certain, that every one OF
them broke his neck. (as he we'll deserved;l
ana the lady lived on IN her wild and virgin
At length, a Young and
handsome knight appeared a. the castle
gate, and requested to be admitted to the
presence Of its mistress, that he might try
his fortune. Cunigunda received him, and
her hour was come; his manly beauty, the
courtesy ofhis behaviour and his noble spir-
it, made her repent, for the first time, of
the price which SHE had set upon her hand.
Having received. in presence of the inmates
of the castle; her promise to become his
bride, if he should return in safety from the

by the tears and wishes Of the repentant
beauty In short time. shout from the
menas announced that the adventure had
been achieved; and Cungunda, exulting that
she was conquered, FASTENED into the court,
which the triumphant knight was Just enter
ing, to meet his ardent carcsSss. But the
knight stood aloof. gloomy and severe. 81
can claim you.' said he, "but am come,
and have risked my life, not to win your
hand, but to humble your harhal'ity.' and
thereupon he read her harsh lecture or
the cruelty and arrogance of her conduct to-
wards her suitors. The spirit OF chivalry
weeps ut recording, that he fiais'ied his ora-
ton by giving the astonished beauty a box
on the ear, sprung into his saddle, and gal

Nav, tell me not, my dearest,


That Time hath dimm'd thine eyes
still, still my path thou cheerest,
As in days that are gone by.
say moi thy cheek is faded,


By sorrows, cares and fears;
That thy brow IS somewhat shaded
By the clouds of darker years.
IfTime much more had taken,


could forgive the theft,
While thy heart remained mistaken,
And its love for me was lclt
j, too, am something older


Than when | met with thee;
But hearts become no colder,


Ifthey are what hearts should be
Thy own has never alter'd,


As wears have DER me past,
Thy love has nel er faltcr'd,


When my brow has been o'crcast;--
Then tell me not Of changes
In cheek, OF brow, or hair
The love such loss cstrlI4gcs,
Must be lighter far than air.
Though mornings early splendor,
May raptnrc's thrill impart,
The vcsper hour, more tender,
Sinks still deeperin the heart.
Tho spring be gay with roses,
And summer skies are clear,
Yet Autumn's hand uncloscs
The rich harvest Of the year.
Fen Ages wintry weather


Inspires no thought of gloom
Hearts which share, together,
In hopes of spring, beyond the tomb.

BEUCHAMP's CONFESSION.

J0nn stark was Dorm AT LONDONDERRY, N.
H. August %, 1928, old style, corresponding
with August II, new style. His father was
native of Scotland and was educated at
the University of Edinburgh-married in
Ireland, and emgrated to America at the
beginning of the centnry.-He made his first
settlement at Londonderry, but soon after
removed to Deerfeld, (now Manchester,)
and settled on the east bank of the Mcrrl-


mack near Amoskeag falls. On the break


ing out Of the seven years war, John Stark,
then 81 years of age, his brother VIII
liam and Amos Eastman Of this town, and
John Stinson OF Londonderry, while out on
a hunting excursion, on the upper branch


es ofthis river, were surprised by the lud-
ans; Stinson was killed on the spot, East


man and John Stark were taken prisoners.
and William Stark escaped. Stark was
conducted by the Indians to Francois, and
from thence to Montreal !; where, after re-


naming four monthsin captivity, he was
purchased by Mr.. Wheelright of Boston and
returned home by way Of Albany. Soou
liter he engaged in company of Rangers,
Of whom he was frs. commissioned lieu
tenant and afterwards captain. Here he
found field suited to his daring and adven-
turous spirit--he remained in the service till
the close of that war; during which he main
tanned the confidence and friendship of the
ish general Howe until the death of
/ that nobleman, who was killed in storming
the French lmes--in that sanguinary and
/ doubtful contest, Stark was always found


cautious on a march, vigalent in camp and


undaunted in battle and it was probably
owing to the experience he here acquired,
that invariabe success attended, so far as he


was concerned, his battles of the subsequent
revolution which separated these states from


Britain.


At the close of the French war he return
ed to his fathers house, was soon after mar
ried and remained in the enjoyment Of do


mestic life, until the report of the battle of
Lexington spread like all electric shock thro'
the country. When this report reached
Stark, he was at work IN his saw mil at
Amoskeag Falls; he stopped his mill, went
Immediately to his house, took his mnsket
and with a band Of heroes, proceeded to
Cambridge. The morning after his arrival
he received colonc's commission and in
less than two hours he enlisted 500 men .
On the memorable II of juno, at Breeds
Hill, the British soldiers felt the destructive
hand of the back wood s-mcn of New Hamp-
shire. Stark, during the whole of this en-
gagement, evinced the most consumate bra
very and intrepid zeal for his country and
his name and heioism viii live forever in
the annals of that cventful period. The
night after this battle, the works OH Winter
Hill were commenced and so jealous were
the soldcry, that on the morrow they pres
ented bold and commanding front, that
kept the British in awe, and prevented fur
ther depredations.


After the British evacuation of Boston,
Stark went TO the northern posts, to assist
the rltreating army from Quebec. On the
arrival of the army at 'Eiconlcroga, the i'm
portant point of Mount Independence was
assigned to his command and the artuons
task of fortifying that peninsula. After the
British quit the lakes, he joined general
Washington in Pennsylvania, preparatory
to the battle Of Trenton. And here it may
be important to notice an event which was
related on tho day of his funeral, by ven
erab,c companion i'll arms, then present =
and in whose veracity the most Implicit re-
lance may be placed. 1t is well known that
just previous to this important action, the
American army was on the point of being
broken up by suffering, dcsertion, and the
expiration OF the term of enlistment of a
portion of the troops. A few days previous,
the term of the New Hampshiro troops ex
p;red:--Stark was the first to propose a re-
engagement for six weeks:--he, for the mo-
ment, left his station as commander, and en-
gagged as recruiting officer; and it is added,
not a man failed to re-engage. He led the
van of this attack the event is we'll
known. Seven days after, he was with Gen.
Washington at Trenton, when lord Corn
wallis with twelve thousand men. nearly
hemmed them in; by consumnate address,
the impending late OF the Americans was a
voided- ashiuston fell on the enemy 'srcar
at Princeton, and so broke up the British
plans that the enfeebled American army was
enabled in turn, to hem up the British in the
environs OF Ncw-Iork.


In Ivy, the overwhelming force of Bur-
goyne drove tne Americans from their
strong post at ficonderoga. Universal a
larm prevailed III the north at the rapid APP
proach of the British. Stark was found ready
TO meet and conquer them. He voluntarily
marched to Vermont, and at the head of I'M
disciplined, but ardent troops, he immortal
lied his name BY planning and consummat- /
ing the attack Mt tnnington-the most ex
traordinary and least expected event Of the
whole revolution, in which two different /
corps of British, Hessian and Indian "lnvin- |
cibles'' were attacked and beaten, in rapid
succcsson:--the first in their redoubts, and
the secoud willie coming up 10 the relief OF
the other. This victory. from state of the
lowest depression, inspired the Americans
with the highest confdence;-Stark, with

From the New-Hampshire Patriot.
GENERAL STARK.

it may probably be effected, when the pow
er Of Omnipotence is interposed.


4 The Transformation of insects afford us
beautiful illustration of this subject All the
butterflies we see huttcring about in the
summer months, were originally catterp-
lars. Before they arrive at that highe,t
stage of their existence, they pass through
four different transformations The first
state of a butterfly is that Of an egg--it next
assumes the form of loathsome crawling
7yorm-after remaining some time in this
state, it throws off its caterpillar skin; Ian
\ guishes; refuses to cat; ceases to move, and
is shut up, as it were, in tomb. In this
state the animal is called chrusdiis-it is CO.
vered with thin crust or she'll, and remains
sometimes for six or eight months without
motion, and apparently without life. After
remaining its allotted time i'll this torpid
condition, it begins to acquire new life and
vigor; it bursts its imprisonment, and comes
forth butterfly, with wings tinged with the
most beautiful colors. 1t mounts the air;
it ranges from flower to flower, and seems
to rejoice in its new and splendid existence.
| How very different does it appear in this
state, from what it did in the preceding
stages ofits existence. How unlikely did it
seem that a rough, hairy, crawling worm,
|
death-like tolpor, and enshrouded in tomb
should lie reaninated, as it were, and Chan
ged into so beautiful form, and endued
with such powers of rapid mstion Perhaps
the change to be effected onthe bodies OF men,
at the general resurrection, may not be
greater, nor more wonderful in its nature,
than are the changes which take place from
the first to the last stage of caterpillar's
existence. In such transformations, then,
we behold lively representation of the death
and resurrection of righteous man. "a
little while he shall lie in the ground, as the
seed lies in the bosom of the earth; but he
shall be raised again, and shall never die any
more"


There is another illustration, taken from
a consideration of the chemical changes of
matter, which has still more direct bearing
on the doctrine OF a re esurrection. We know
| that substances which are invisibly incnrpo.
rated with air, water, and other fluids, and
which seem to be destroyed, may be made
to re-appear in their original form by the
application of certain chemical Reagents
For example, put a small piece of solid cam
phor into phial half-hlle with alcohol or
| spirits of wine; in short time the camphor
will be dissolved in the fluid, and the spirits
will be as transparent as at first. II water
be now added, it will unite with the ardent
spirit, and the camphor will be separated,
and fall to the bottom OF the phial In this
way the camphor may be nearly all recov-
cred as at first; and by distillation the alco-
hol may also be separated from the water,
and exhibited in separate state | have
already noticed that carbon. which forms an
essential part of animal and vegetable sub
stances, is found to be not only indestrucu-
bic by age, but, in all its combinations, which
are Infinitely diversified, it still preserves its
identity. In the state OF carbonic acid 1t
exists In union with earths and stones III un-
bounded quantities; and though buried tor
thousands of years beneath immense rocks
or IN the centre of mountains, it is still car
bonlc acid; for no sooner is it disengaged
from its dormitory than it rises with all the
life and vigour of recent formation, not in the
least impaired by its torpid inactivity during
a lapse of ages The beams of the theatre
at Hercuaneum were converted into char
coal, (Which is one of the compounds of car
bon) by the lava which overtlawcd that city,
during an eruption of Mount Vesuvus; and
during the lapse OF 1T00 years, the charcoal
has remained as entire as ifit had been form
ed but yesterday, and it will probably con-
tinue so to the end of the world


In addition to these facts it may be stated
that provision has been made for the res
toration of the fallen leaves of vegetables
which rot upon the gronnd, and, to a care
less observer, would appear to be lost forev-
er 1t has been shown by experiment, that
whenever the soil becomes charged with
such matter, the oxygen of the atmosphere
combines with it. and converts it into car
bonic acid gas. The consequence of which
is, that this 1ery same carbon is in process
of time, absorbed bv new race of vegeta-
bles which it clothes with a new foliage,
and which is itself destined to undergo SINH
lar putrefaction ard renovation to the end of
time.


These facts, and others Of a similar des-
cription which might have been stated, de-
monstrate, that one of the constituent parts
of animal bodies remain unalterably the
same, amidst all the revolutions of time, and
all the changes and decompositions which
take place in the system of nature; and, con-
sequently, that though human bodies may
remain in state of putrefaction for ages, in
the earth and in the waters. yet their COM
ponent parts remain unchanged, and in read
mess to enter into new and more glorious
combination, at the command of that lntelli-
gence, to whom all the principles OF nature,
and all their diversified changes, are inti-
mately known; and whose Power is able to
direct their combinations to the accomplish
ment of his purposes.


Tho such!consideratnns as these may have

the horizon, night was fast approaching, and
the poor Wanderer knew not where to rest
his weary limbs. Fatigued and almost
exhausted, he came at last near village
He was glad to find it inhabited, thinking
where human beings dwelt, there dwelt al
so humanity and compassion, but he was
mistaken. He asked for nights lodging,
it was refused. Not one of the inhospitable

was therefore obliged to seek shelter in a
neighboring wood. 1t is hard, said he, not
to find hospitable roof to protect me against
the inclemency Of the weather; bur God is
Just, and zvhatever he does is for the best,
He seated himself beneath tree, lighted
his lamp, and began to read the La7v. He
had scarcely read chapter, when violent
storm extnguished the light. WHAT ex-
claimed he, must not be permitted even
to pursue my favourite study' Bur God is
Just, and zvhateUer he does is for the best


HE stretched himself on the bare earth.
willing, if possible to have a few hours
sleep. He had scarcely closed his eyes,
when fierce wolf came and killed the cock
What new misfortune is this!' calculated
the astonished Akiba.-'My vigilant compan-


ion is gone Who then, will henceforth a.
waken me to the study of the law9 But,
God is just; he knows best zuhat is good for
lts hoor mortais.-Scarcely had he fin


shed the sentence, when terrible lion
came and devoured his ass,--'What is to be
done now exclaimed the lonely wanderer,
my lamp and my cock are gone; my poor
ass too is gone--all is gone But hraised
be the Lord, qvhate1er he does is for the best


He passed sleepess night, and early in


the morning went to the village, to see


whether he could procure horse, or any


beast Of burden, to enable him to pursue his
journey. But what was his surprise, not to
| find single individual alive


sit appears that band ofrobbers had en-
tered the village during the night, killed its
inhabitants, and plundered their houses. AS
soon as Akiba had sufficiently recovered
from the amazement into which this won-
derful occurrence had thrown him, he lifted
up his voice and exclaimed, Thou Great
God, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
now know by experience, that poor mortal


men are short sighted and blind, often con-
sdcri2s as evils, what is intended tor their
preservation! But thou alone art kind and
mercifu! Had not the hard-hearted peo-
Pile driven ME by their inhospitality from the
village. should assuredly have shared their
fate. Had not the wind extinguished my
lamp the robbers would have been drawn to
the spot, and have murdered me. l per-
ceve also that it was thy mercy which de-
prived me of my two companions, that they
! might not by their noise, give notice to the
banditti where was. Praised, then, be thy
name for ever and ever!"

pally employed with general Gates, in sur
veying the country from Tiverton to Point
Judith, to guard against attack. Late in the
season, however, he joined Washington with
the northern army, who was enabled to
make good his winter quarters. In the year
1880, he was with Washington at Morris
town and 10 the battle of Springheld that
season terminated with Gen. Lincoln's dis
aster at Charleston and the treason of Ar
nold In '81 he again had charge OF the
northern department and kept the enemy in
close quarters with small body of milltia;
the surrender OF Corn wallis this year, closed
the war.


For the materials of this hasty sketch,
our obligations are due to major Caleb Stark
his eldest son, who participated with his IL
lustrious father in many OF the perls OF the
revolution.


At the conclusion of the war, General
Stark, like the Roman Cincinnatus, retired
to the pursuits of domestic life, mingling
with the illustrious and hardy yeomanry Of
New England, and aspiring to none OF the
honors CT emolunents Of public Office; but
reaping, IN common with his countrymen,
the fruits Of that immortal struggle which
made us free people. For the last few
years OF his life, he enjoyed pecuniary
bounty from Governmental free will offer
ing Of the nation to ONT. Of its most ditinguish
ed defenders.


Such was General Stark ,---the last surviv-
ing general officer of the rcyulution--the
first and most intrepid hero Of cur state, Of


whom she may justly boast, as unsurpassed
in cool and determined bravery. lie has
gone the way Of all the living. His charac-
ter in private life was unembellished. Hi,


manners were frank and artless, though
tnged with an eccentrlcity peculiar to hi.
family alone. 10 sam up all, he was tina,
"nobest work of God" an honest man.

full articles.headline: TIE BET Err LAND.
full articles.article:
By Hrs. Hemans
az hear thee sing of Better Land,
Thou call'st its children happy band;
Mother! oh, where is that radiant shore
Shall we not seek it and weep no more'
Is it where the flower of the orange blows,
And the fire-fies glance through the myrtle.


boughsp'


-"Not there, not there, my child"
'Is it where the fcathery palln-trees rise,
And the dale grows ripe Under sunny skies
Or midst the green island of glttering seas,
VIII re fragrant forests perfume the breeze,
And strange, bright birds on their starry wings,
Bear the rich hues of all glorious things"


--s'Not there, not there, my child"
SIS it far away in some region old,
Where the rivers wander DER sands of gold
Where the burning rays Of the ruby shine,
And the diamond lights up the secret mine,
And the pearl CLEANS forth from the coral strand
Is it there, sweet mother, that better landN'


-"Not there, not there, my child
"Eyc hath not seen it, my gentle boy!
Ear hath not heard lis deep songs Of joy,
Dreams cannot picture world so fair
Sorrow and death may not enter there;
Time doth not breathe on its fadelcss bloom,
Far beyond the clouds and beyond the tomb,


1t is there, it is there, my childF"

full articles.headline: DEVILS WALL.
full articles.article:
This famous wall which formerly sepa-


rated England from Scotland, many parts of


which still exist, and which even time has


not injured. The strength of the cement
and the hardness of the stone have persuad-
ed the inhabitants of the adjoining district
that it was built by the hand of the devil;
and the more superstitous amongst them
are very anxious to collect the smallest re-


mains of it. which they mix with the foun-
dation OF their houses, in order to give them
greater solility. A Scotch gardener, on


digging in the soil of his garden, found


stone of considerable size, upon which


was an inscription in the dialect of the peri


cd, purportlng that it had been placed there


for the security OF the walls ofthe castle and


of the garden, and that it had been brought
thther from the great wall, of which it had
formerly constituted part; but that there


would be as much danger in moving it. as
there would be advantage in leaving it in its
place. The owner of the estate, who was
less credulols than this ancestors. wished to
have it transported to another spot, in order
to expose it to public view as an ancient
monument. Workmen were employed to
raise it from the ground by means of ma
chinery, and they succeeded, as they would
have done with a common stone. 1t remain
Gu ui''u tHS St5C VI lHC WuDC tulioa-
ity induced several persons to descend into
the cavity, amongst the rest the gardener,
several servants and the two sons OF the
proprietor, who amused themselves for some
time il digging in the hole. The fatal stone
which had not been placed in a just equili-
brium, chose that moment for falling to the
bottom Of the cavity, and crushed all those
who were in it. The young wife of the ell
der ofthe two brothers soon learnt what had
She hurried to the garden, with
the wild transports of u woman who has no
thing left in the world TO care for; and she
arrived at the time when the workmen were
using their utmost efforts to raise the stone
again, ii the faint hope of finding some re-
mains Of life in the unfortunate sufferers
whom it covered. They had half raised it,
and it was in fact perceived, by certain


that they still breathed, when
the imprudent wife, losing all care tor her
self threw herself so precipitately on the
body Of her husband, that the workmen,
petrined BY her action, unfortunately let go
the machines which supported the stone,
and buried her VITA the others. This acci-
dent still further confirmed the superstition
Of the Scotch; they failed not to attribute it
to some power established for the preserva.
tion of the wall of Scotland, and all OF the
stones which have been detached from il.

full articles.headline: From Dicks Christian Philosopher.
full articles.article:
From Dicks Christian Philosopher.


The discoveries which have been made in the


System of Nature illustrate the doctrine of the


Resurrection ofthe dead.


The Doctrine of Resurrection of the
DEAD, at hrSt view, appears to involve III IT
a variety of difficulties and apparent con-
tradictions. That a complex organical ma
chine, as the human body is, consisting of
thousands of diversified parts, for the per-
formance of its functions, after being reduced
70 atoms, and those atoms scattered to "the
four winds of Heavcn"-should be again
reared up with the same materials, in a new
and more glorious form, is an idea which
seems to battle the human comprehen
sion; and. in all probability, would never
nave entered the mind of man, had it not
neen communicated by Divine Revelation
Accordingly, we find that the philosophers
OF antiquity, though many Of them believed
IN future state, never once dreamed that
The bodies of men, after they had been COM
mitted to the dust, would ever again be re-
animated; and hence, when the Apostle
raul proposed this doctrine to the Athenian
philosophers, they secuted the idea, as if it
mad been the reverie of madman. And,
nideed, without strong conviction, and a
hvely impression of the infinite power and
intelligence of God, the mind cannot rely
with mistaken confidence on the declaration
Sl =, future fact so widely different from all
.,le OBVIOUS phenomena of nature, and from
every thing that lies within the range of hu.
man experience. "If man tlie," says Job,
snail he live again? There is hope of a
.ree, 1t be cut down, that it will sprout a.
haalh' a' and bring forth boughs like plant
Out nas man dicth and wasteth away, yea, man
5MWeth up the ghost, and where is hee"
maen the mind. however, is frequently ex-
asas s,ssed IN contemplations on the stupendous
nraa nurks OF the Almighty, it must feel an i'm
Sssslve Sars conviction, "that nothing can be too
ths1 husa ior Jehovah" When we endeavor to
shs INV aside the veil which conceals many of
|IIls s.enes OF nature from the vulgar eye,

In the number of the London Quarterly
Review Just received, some amusing extracts
are made from "Eurwitz's Hcbre.v fatc@,
selected from the writings of the ancient
Hebrew sagcs. The following specimen is
given:


"Compelled by violent persecution to
quit his native land, Rabbi Akiba wandered
over barren wastes and dreary deserts. His
whole equipage consisted Ola lamp, which
he used to light at night, in order to study
the law; cock, which served him instead
of watch, to announce to him the rising
dawn: and an ass, on which he rode.


"rhe SIN was gradually sinking beneath

full articles.headline: REPRooF.
full articles.article:
On scanty and bold projection of rock,


stands the ruins Of the Kienast, SO separat-


ed on all sides from the body of the noun


tain, by PERCEPTIONS hills, except where a


narrow hedge en the south connects it with


the hill, that the rising of a single draw


bride must have rendered it inaccessible


Enough Of TIE outer wall still remains, to


preserve tic memory of the fair Cunigunda,


equally celebrated for her charms and her


cruelty. She was the daughter and heiress


of the lord Of kienast, and the most bloom


inr of Silesian BEAUTIES. Her wealth and


charms attracted crowds of the knigty WOO


ers to her fathers castle; but the maiden,


like another Camilla, was entirely devoted


to the boisterous exercise of the chase, in


which. she excelled manv of her suffers; she


would listen to no tale of love, and dreaded


marriage as she did pr son. At length to


free herself from all opportunities She made


a solemn vow, never to give her hand but to
the knight who should ride round the castle
on the outer wall. Now, this wall is not
only too narrow to furnish secure or pleas
ing promenade in any circumstances, but
throughout nearly its whole course, it runs a
long the very brink of hideous precipices,
and in one place hangs over frghttul a
bvse, which, till this day, bears the name OF
Hell The number of the lady 8 lovers rap


dly diminished. The more prudent wise
ly considered that the prize was not worth
the risk; the vain proposed themselves to
the trial IN the hope that their presence
would molly Cungunda's heart, and procure
a lispensution from the hard condition; but
the mountain beauty was proof against all
arts, and when the moment OF danger came,
the courage of the suitor generally gave
way. History has not recorded the precise
number of those who actually made the at
tempt, it IS only certain, that every one OF
them broke his neck. (as he we'll deserved;l
ana the lady lived on IN her wild and virgin
At length, a Young and
handsome knight appeared a. the castle
gate, and requested to be admitted to the
presence Of its mistress, that he might try
his fortune. Cunigunda received him, and
her hour was come; his manly beauty, the
courtesy ofhis behaviour and his noble spir-
it, made her repent, for the first time, of
the price which SHE had set upon her hand.
Having received. in presence of the inmates
of the castle; her promise to become his
bride, if he should return in safety from the
trial, he rode forth to the wall, accompanied
by the tears and wishes Of the repentant
beauty In short time. shout from the
menas announced that the adventure had
been achieved; and Cungunda, exulting that
she was conquered, FASTENED into the court,
which the triumphant knight was Just enter
ing, to meet his ardent carcsSss. But the
knight stood aloof. gloomy and severe. 81
can claim you.' said he, "but am come,
and have risked my life, not to win your
hand, but to humble your harhal'ity.' and
thereupon he read her harsh lecture or
the cruelty and arrogance of her conduct to-
wards her suitors. The spirit OF chivalry
weeps ut recording, that he fiais'ied his ora-
ton by giving the astonished beauty a box
on the ear, sprung into his saddle, and gal
loped from the gate. 1t was the I.andgrave
Albert, of Thurineia, already married
man, and who had long trained his favourite
steed to this perilous exercise.

full articles.headline:
IPD-HzEl13sYe

s1'ANZAs.
full articles.article:
Nav, tell me not, my dearest,


That Time hath dimm'd thine eyes
still, still my path thou cheerest,
As in days that are gone by.
say moi thy cheek is faded,


By sorrows, cares and fears;
That thy brow IS somewhat shaded
By the clouds of darker years.
IfTime much more had taken,


could forgive the theft,
While thy heart remained mistaken,
And its love for me was lclt
j, too, am something older


Than when | met with thee;
But hearts become no colder,


Ifthey are what hearts should be
Thy own has never alter'd,


As wears have DER me past,
Thy love has nel er faltcr'd,


When my brow has been o'crcast;--
Then tell me not Of changes
In cheek, OF brow, or hair
The love such loss cstrlI4gcs,
Must be lighter far than air.
Though mornings early splendor,
May raptnrc's thrill impart,
The vcsper hour, more tender,
Sinks still deeperin the heart.
Tho spring be gay with roses,
And summer skies are clear,
Yet Autumn's hand uncloscs
The rich harvest Of the year.
Fen Ages wintry weather


Inspires no thought of gloom
Hearts which share, together,
In hopes of spring, beyond the tomb.

full articles.article:

Gently made its appearance in Kentucky.

full articles.headline:
From the New-Hampshire Patriot.
GENERAL STARK.
full articles.article:
J0nn stark was Dorm AT LONDONDERRY, N.
H. August %, 1928, old style, corresponding
with August II, new style. His father was
native of Scotland and was educated at
the University of Edinburgh-married in
Ireland, and emgrated to America at the
beginning of the centnry.-He made his first
settlement at Londonderry, but soon after
removed to Deerfeld, (now Manchester,)
and settled on the east bank of the Mcrrl-


mack near Amoskeag falls. On the break


ing out Of the seven years war, John Stark,
then 81 years of age, his brother VIII
liam and Amos Eastman Of this town, and
John Stinson OF Londonderry, while out on
a hunting excursion, on the upper branch


es ofthis river, were surprised by the lud-
ans; Stinson was killed on the spot, East


man and John Stark were taken prisoners.
and William Stark escaped. Stark was
conducted by the Indians to Francois, and
from thence to Montreal !; where, after re-


naming four monthsin captivity, he was
purchased by Mr.. Wheelright of Boston and
returned home by way Of Albany. Soou
liter he engaged in company of Rangers,
Of whom he was frs. commissioned lieu
tenant and afterwards captain. Here he
found field suited to his daring and adven-
turous spirit--he remained in the service till
the close of that war; during which he main
tanned the confidence and friendship of the
ish general Howe until the death of
/ that nobleman, who was killed in storming
the French lmes--in that sanguinary and
/ doubtful contest, Stark was always found


cautious on a march, vigalent in camp and


undaunted in battle and it was probably
owing to the experience he here acquired,
that invariabe success attended, so far as he


was concerned, his battles of the subsequent
revolution which separated these states from


Britain.


At the close of the French war he return
ed to his fathers house, was soon after mar
ried and remained in the enjoyment Of do


mestic life, until the report of the battle of
Lexington spread like all electric shock thro'
the country. When this report reached
Stark, he was at work IN his saw mil at
Amoskeag Falls; he stopped his mill, went
Immediately to his house, took his mnsket
and with a band Of heroes, proceeded to
Cambridge. The morning after his arrival
he received colonc's commission and in
less than two hours he enlisted 500 men .
On the memorable II of juno, at Breeds
Hill, the British soldiers felt the destructive
hand of the back wood s-mcn of New Hamp-
shire. Stark, during the whole of this en-
gagement, evinced the most consumate bra
very and intrepid zeal for his country and
his name and heioism viii live forever in
the annals of that cventful period. The
night after this battle, the works OH Winter
Hill were commenced and so jealous were
the soldcry, that on the morrow they pres
ented bold and commanding front, that
kept the British in awe, and prevented fur
ther depredations.


After the British evacuation of Boston,
Stark went TO the northern posts, to assist
the rltreating army from Quebec. On the
arrival of the army at 'Eiconlcroga, the i'm
portant point of Mount Independence was
assigned to his command and the artuons
task of fortifying that peninsula. After the
British quit the lakes, he joined general
Washington in Pennsylvania, preparatory
to the battle Of Trenton. And here it may
be important to notice an event which was
related on tho day of his funeral, by ven
erab,c companion i'll arms, then present =
and in whose veracity the most Implicit re-
lance may be placed. 1t is well known that
just previous to this important action, the
American army was on the point of being
broken up by suffering, dcsertion, and the
expiration OF the term of enlistment of a
portion of the troops. A few days previous,
the term of the New Hampshiro troops ex
p;red:--Stark was the first to propose a re-
engagement for six weeks:--he, for the mo-
ment, left his station as commander, and en-
gagged as recruiting officer; and it is added,
not a man failed to re-engage. He led the
van of this attack the event is we'll
known. Seven days after, he was with Gen.
Washington at Trenton, when lord Corn
wallis with twelve thousand men. nearly
hemmed them in; by consumnate address,
the impending late OF the Americans was a
voided- ashiuston fell on the enemy 'srcar
at Princeton, and so broke up the British
plans that the enfeebled American army was
enabled in turn, to hem up the British in the
environs OF Ncw-Iork.


In Ivy, the overwhelming force of Bur-
goyne drove tne Americans from their
strong post at ficonderoga. Universal a
larm prevailed III the north at the rapid APP
proach of the British. Stark was found ready
TO meet and conquer them. He voluntarily
marched to Vermont, and at the head of I'M
disciplined, but ardent troops, he immortal
lied his name BY planning and consummat- /
ing the attack Mt tnnington-the most ex
traordinary and least expected event Of the
whole revolution, in which two different /
corps of British, Hessian and Indian "lnvin- |
cibles'' were attacked and beaten, in rapid
succcsson:--the first in their redoubts, and
the secoud willie coming up 10 the relief OF
the other. This victory. from state of the
lowest depression, inspired the Americans
with the highest confdence;-Stark, with


- IL. ,.,Sn ~

it may probably be effected, when the pow
er Of Omnipotence is interposed.


4 The Transformation of insects afford us
beautiful illustration of this subject All the
butterflies we see huttcring about in the
summer months, were originally catterp-
lars. Before they arrive at that highe,t
stage of their existence, they pass through
four different transformations The first
state of a butterfly is that Of an egg--it next
assumes the form of loathsome crawling
7yorm-after remaining some time in this
state, it throws off its caterpillar skin; Ian
\ guishes; refuses to cat; ceases to move, and
is shut up, as it were, in tomb. In this
state the animal is called chrusdiis-it is CO.
vered with thin crust or she'll, and remains
sometimes for six or eight months without
motion, and apparently without life. After
remaining its allotted time i'll this torpid
condition, it begins to acquire new life and
vigor; it bursts its imprisonment, and comes
forth butterfly, with wings tinged with the
most beautiful colors. 1t mounts the air;
it ranges from flower to flower, and seems
to rejoice in its new and splendid existence.
| How very different does it appear in this
state, from what it did in the preceding
stages ofits existence. How unlikely did it
seem that a rough, hairy, crawling worm,
|
death-like tolpor, and enshrouded in tomb
should lie reaninated, as it were, and Chan
ged into so beautiful form, and endued
with such powers of rapid mstion Perhaps
the change to be effected onthe bodies OF men,
at the general resurrection, may not be
greater, nor more wonderful in its nature,
than are the changes which take place from
the first to the last stage of caterpillar's
existence. In such transformations, then,
we behold lively representation of the death
and resurrection of righteous man. "a
little while he shall lie in the ground, as the
seed lies in the bosom of the earth; but he
shall be raised again, and shall never die any
more"


There is another illustration, taken from
a consideration of the chemical changes of
matter, which has still more direct bearing
on the doctrine OF a re esurrection. We know
| that substances which are invisibly incnrpo.
rated with air, water, and other fluids, and
which seem to be destroyed, may be made
to re-appear in their original form by the
application of certain chemical Reagents
For example, put a small piece of solid cam
phor into phial half-hlle with alcohol or
| spirits of wine; in short time the camphor
will be dissolved in the fluid, and the spirits
will be as transparent as at first. II water
be now added, it will unite with the ardent
spirit, and the camphor will be separated,
and fall to the bottom OF the phial In this
way the camphor may be nearly all recov-
cred as at first; and by distillation the alco-
hol may also be separated from the water,
and exhibited in separate state | have
already noticed that carbon. which forms an
essential part of animal and vegetable sub
stances, is found to be not only indestrucu-
bic by age, but, in all its combinations, which
are Infinitely diversified, it still preserves its
identity. In the state OF carbonic acid 1t
exists In union with earths and stones III un-
bounded quantities; and though buried tor
thousands of years beneath immense rocks
or IN the centre of mountains, it is still car
bonlc acid; for no sooner is it disengaged
from its dormitory than it rises with all the
life and vigour of recent formation, not in the
least impaired by its torpid inactivity during
a lapse of ages The beams of the theatre
at Hercuaneum were converted into char
coal, (Which is one of the compounds of car
bon) by the lava which overtlawcd that city,
during an eruption of Mount Vesuvus; and
during the lapse OF 1T00 years, the charcoal
has remained as entire as ifit had been form
ed but yesterday, and it will probably con-
tinue so to the end of the world


In addition to these facts it may be stated
that provision has been made for the res
toration of the fallen leaves of vegetables
which rot upon the gronnd, and, to a care
less observer, would appear to be lost forev-
er 1t has been shown by experiment, that
whenever the soil becomes charged with
such matter, the oxygen of the atmosphere
combines with it. and converts it into car
bonic acid gas. The consequence of which
is, that this 1ery same carbon is in process
of time, absorbed bv new race of vegeta-
bles which it clothes with a new foliage,
and which is itself destined to undergo SINH
lar putrefaction ard renovation to the end of
time.


These facts, and others Of a similar des-
cription which might have been stated, de-
monstrate, that one of the constituent parts
of animal bodies remain unalterably the
same, amidst all the revolutions of time, and
all the changes and decompositions which
take place in the system of nature; and, con-
sequently, that though human bodies may
remain in state of putrefaction for ages, in
the earth and in the waters. yet their COM
ponent parts remain unchanged, and in read
mess to enter into new and more glorious
combination, at the command of that lntelli-
gence, to whom all the principles OF nature,
and all their diversified changes, are inti-
mately known; and whose Power is able to
direct their combinations to the accomplish
ment of his purposes.


Tho such!consideratnns as these may have
